readings: The True Story of Ah Q (Lu Xun)

readingAnalyses.title: The True Story of Ah Q
readingAnalyses.author: Lu Xun (鲁迅)
readingAnalyses.source: Yang Hsien-yi and Gladys Yang translation (Peking: Foreign Languages Press, 1960)
readingAnalyses.summary:
Lu Xun's satirical novella, serialized in the Beijing Morning Post supplement from December 1921 to February 1922, creates Ah Q: a rural day-laborer in the fictional village of Weichuang who survives every humiliation through 'spiritual victories,' mental gymnastics that transform defeats into triumphs. Beaten by stronger men? 'It is as if I were beaten by my son.' Robbed of his silver? Slap your own face until it feels like you slapped someone else.

The novella's nine chapters trace Ah Q through escalating crises: social humiliation, failed romantic pursuit, petty theft, and the arrival of the 1911 Revolution. The revolution chapters are the satirical core. Ah Q embraces revolution as a chance to become the bully: 'I shall take what I want! I shall like whom I please!' But the village elite simply cut their queues, call themselves revolutionaries, and bar Ah Q from joining. The revolution changes costumes, not structures.

In the final chapter, Ah Q is arrested for a robbery he didn't commit, tried before a court he doesn't understand, and asked to sign a confession he can't write. He tries to draw a circle instead and produces 'a shape like a melon seed.' He is executed. The crowd is disappointed because the shooting wasn't as entertaining as a decapitation.

Lu Xun's target was not one fictional character but China itself. Ah Q embodies what Lu Xun diagnosed as national pathologies: self-deception, bullying the weak while submitting to the strong, claiming moral victories while losing every actual battle. This self-critical nationalism differs sharply from the defensive nationalisms of Korea (Plate 18) and the expansionist nationalism of Japan (Plate 17).

keyQuotes.quote: It is as if I were beaten by my son. What is the world coming to nowadays. . . .

Raising his right hand he slapped his own face hard twice, so that it tingled with pain. After this slapping his heart felt lighter, for it seemed as if the one who had given the slap was himself, the one slapped some other self, and soon it was just as if he had beaten someone else.
Revolution is not a bad thing. Finish off the whole lot of them . . . curse them! . . . I would like to go over to the revolutionaries myself.

Most people were dissatisfied, because a shooting was not such a fine spectacle as a decapitation; and what a ridiculous culprit he had been too, to pass through so many streets without singing a single line from an opera.

thematicExamples: Spiritual victory method — Ah Q reinterprets every defeat as a psychological triumph (pp. 10-13)
Bullying hierarchy — Ah Q abuses those weaker (the nun, Whiskers Wang) while submitting to the Chao family (pp. 14-19, 29-35)
Revolution as farce — the 1911 revolution changes decorations but not structures in Weichuang (pp. 44-51)
The circle scene — Ah Q tries to draw a perfect circle as his death warrant and fails (p. 62)
Crowd as spectacle — the execution audience is disappointed by the lack of entertainment value (p. 67)
realLifeConnections: The 'Ah Q spirit' (阿Q精神) became a permanent Chinese term for self-deception in the face of defeat
Lu Xun's approach influenced generations of Chinese intellectuals attacking tradition
May Fourth Movement context — radical questioning of Chinese culture's worth
The novella is still taught in Chinese schools; the concept is still used in Chinese media
Contemporary debates over whether Lu Xun's critique of 'national character' is valid social analysis or essentialism

authorBios.name: Lu Xun
authorBios.nameCn: 鲁迅 (birth name: Zhou Shuren 周树人)
authorBios.bio: Born into a declining scholar-gentry family in Shaoxing, Zhejiang. Grandfather imprisoned for examination fraud (1893), father died after futile traditional medicine treatments (1896). Studied medicine in Sendai, Japan (1904-1906); abandoned it after the lantern slide incident. Published 'Diary of a Madman' (1918), the first major modern Chinese story written in vernacular. 'The True Story of Ah Q' (1921-22) became his most famous work. Led the League of Left-Wing Writers (1930). Never joined the Communist Party but moved steadily leftward. Died of tuberculosis in Shanghai, October 19, 1936. Coffin draped with banner reading 'Soul of the Nation' (民族魂). Mao later canonized him as 'the commander of China's cultural revolution.'

overallSynthesis:
Lu Xun's 'Ah Q' represents a distinctively Chinese form of nationalism: self-critical rather than defensive, attacking Chinese culture to save the Chinese nation. Where Korean nationalists (Plate 18) emphasized victimhood and moral superiority, Lu Xun insisted that Chinese weakness invited foreign aggression. The cure wasn't just expelling invaders but transforming Chinese culture itself.

This connects to the May Fourth Movement's radical agenda: destroy the 'old China' of Confucianism, hierarchy, and submission to create a 'new China' capable of standing among nations. Lu Xun himself was skeptical of easy solutions. He saw the 1911 revolution as farce, nationalism as potentially another form of self-deception. His critique cut deeper than politics to the level of culture and psychology.

Comparing the three nationalisms: Japanese nationalism (Plate 17) was expansionist and confident. Korean nationalism (Plate 18) was defensive and moral. Chinese nationalism (Plate 19) was self-critical and satirical. All three emerged from encounters with Western imperialism; all three would shape twentieth-century East Asian history; but they started from fundamentally different diagnoses of what the problem was.
executiveSummary:
Lu Xun (1881-1936) is considered modern China's greatest writer. 'The True Story of Ah Q' (1921-22) is a satirical novella about a rural day-laborer who transforms every humiliation into a 'spiritual victory' through self-deception. Lu Xun's target was China itself: a culture that taught people to claim psychological triumphs while suffering actual defeats.

The novella's nine chapters move from social comedy to political satire to tragedy. Ah Q's 'spiritual victory method' is the core: beaten and humiliated, he reinterprets each loss as a win. The revolution chapters (7-8) show the 1911 Revolution arriving in a village where nothing actually changes. The final chapter's execution scene, with Ah Q failing to draw a circle as his confession, is among the most famous moments in Chinese literature.

This self-critical nationalism stands in stark contrast to the defensive Korean nationalism of Plate 18 and the expansionist Japanese nationalism of Plate 17. Lu Xun believed China's problems were internal, not just external. The cure was cultural transformation, not just expelling foreigners.

keyQuestions.question: What is the 'spiritual victory method' and why did Lu Xun find it so dangerous?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Track every instance of Ah Q reinterpreting defeat as victory. The method escalates from mild rationalization (p. 10) to self-harm (p. 13). Lu Xun saw this as China's national response to humiliation. Is some psychological coping necessary? Where's the line between resilience and self-deception?

keyQuestions.question: What actually changes in Weichuang after the 1911 Revolution?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: The gentry cut their queues and call themselves revolutionaries. The power structure is untouched. Ah Q gets excluded, then executed. Lu Xun is arguing that political revolution without cultural transformation is meaningless. Do you agree?

keyQuestions.question: How does Chinese nationalism (Lu Xun's version) differ from Korean and Japanese nationalism?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Japanese: expansionist, 'we are strong.' Korean: defensive, 'we are wronged.' Chinese: self-critical, 'we are sick.' All three respond to Western imperialism but diagnose completely different problems. Which diagnosis was most accurate?

keyQuestions.question: Is Lu Xun's critique of 'Chinese national character' valid social analysis or essentialism?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Lu Xun was attacking specific behaviors he saw as products of Confucian hierarchy. But 'national character' arguments can slide into stereotyping entire peoples. How do we take his critique seriously without accepting essentialist premises?

connections.fromPrevious: Plates 17-18 examined Japanese and Korean nationalism. Chinese nationalism has a different character: more self-critical, more focused on internal transformation. Where Korean nationalists blamed Japan, Lu Xun blamed China.
connections.toNext: Plate 20 examines civil war and revolution in China. The radical self-critique of the May Fourth generation fed into both Nationalist and Communist revolutionary movements.
connections.broaderThemes: Three East Asian nationalisms, three completely different diagnoses. Japanese: 'We need power.' Korean: 'We need justice.' Chinese: 'We need to change ourselves.' All responding to the same Western-imposed crisis.

teachingNotes: Ah Q is darkly funny. Let students laugh, then discuss why it's disturbing.
The spiritual victory method is the core concept. Track every instance across chapters.
Compare the three nationalisms explicitly: Japan (power), Korea (justice), China (self-transformation).
The circle scene (p. 62) is worth close reading. Why does Lu Xun make this the climax?
The crowd at the execution (p. 67) mirrors the lantern slide incident that made Lu Xun abandon medicine.
Lu Xun is still taught in Chinese schools but his critique cuts against official nationalism. Good discussion topic.
Ask students: is 'spiritual victory' unique to China or a universal human response to defeat?
